text: Hi, this is Wallace from Epic Games. In
this video, I will show you one of the
new features in Reality Scan 2.0, AI
masking. This feature gives you the
ability to scan entire objects without
the use of specialist equipment. You
just need to make sure you get photos of
your object from every angle. You can
either use a turntable or just rotate
the object by hand. Make sure the
lighting is even and consistent. Avoid
placing any other objects too close to
or directly behind the subject you're
scanning as they could accidentally be
included in the mask. For the cleanest
mask, try placing your object against a
background that's one solid color and
make sure it completely surrounds the
subject. Even with a high-end void
capture setup, using AI masking is still
recommended. Without it, you might still
get tie points in the background. Now,
just stick to the basic rules of
capturing high resolution images.
Maintain strong overlap, ideally 70% or
more, and keep the angle changes
gradual, staying within 20° from shot to
shot. Okay, let's get into it. Now, here
is a project I made earlier, and I've
already run AI masks um because it takes
quite a while. Um, you can find it in
workflow process and right here if I
just clicked that it would mask all of
my images. There's also a drop down here
and this button does the same and we'll
go into the others just afterwards. So,
uh, here is my image. You can click on
any in your 1DS here and see it in your
2D if you've made a 2D view like go down
to 2D here and I've got turquoise
background just to make it a bit more
obvious. you probably would want to go

as if you had normal masks and we can

background disappeared and the camera
cameras find their relative positions to
